[[Image:BadVista no littering.svg|right|125px]] '''BadVista''' was a campaign by the [[Free Software Foundation]] to oppose adoption of [[Microsoft]] [[Windows Vista]] and promote [[free software]] alternatives. A follow-up to the [[Defective by Design]] campaign against [[digital rights management]] technologies, it aimed to encourage the media to make free software part of their agenda.<ref name="Linux Journal">{{cite news |title=Looking into the FSF's BadVista campaign |url=http://www.linuxjournal.com/node/1000148 |publisher=linuxjournal.com |accessdate=2007-08-11 }}</ref> The campaign lasted from December 2006 to January 2009.
== History == [[Image:VistaParty3-cropped.jpg|right|thumb|Bad Vista activists from [[Boston]]]] The campaign was initiated on December 15, 2006 with aims to expose what it views as the harms inflicted on computer users by Microsoft [[Windows Vista]] and its embedded [[digital rights management]], as well as providing a user-friendly gateway to free software alternatives.<ref>{{cite web |title=BadVista.org: FSF launches campaign against Microsoft Vista |url=http://badvista.fsf.org/blog/launch-press-release |author=John Sullivan |accessdate=2007-08-11 }}</ref><ref name=bb/>
BadVista activists teamed up with [[Defective by Design]] members on a Vista launch party on January 30, 2007 at the [[Times Square]]. Protesters in hazmat suits held their signs explaining the restrictions Vista may impose on computer users.<ref name=bb>{{cite web | url = http://www.boingboing.net/2007/01/29/defective-by-design-.html | title = Defective by Design pickets Vista launch in NYC | date = January 29, 2007 | publisher = boingboing.net | accessdate=2009-06-09}}</ref><ref name="New York Vista launch party">{{cite web | url = http://badvista.fsf.org/blog/a-badvista-at-microsofts-new-york-launch-parties | title = A BadVista at Microsoft's New York launch parties | author = John Sullivan | date = January 30, 2007 | publisher = BadVista.org | accessdate=2008-01-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://zedomax.com/blog/2008/05/25/are-you-being-naughty-microsoft-bad-vista-accounting/ | title = Are you being naughty Microsoft? - Bad Vista Accounting | date = Sunday, May 25, 2008 | publisher = zedomax.com | accessdate=2009-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://linmagazine.co.il/node/view/34012 | title = ×××©×§× '×××¡××'. ××××. | date = 2007-01-30 | publisher = linmagazine.co.il | accessdate=2009-06-09}}</ref> The campaign ended on January 8, 2009, when "victory" was declared after Microsoft released its [[Windows 7]] [[Beta software|Beta]].<ref>{{cite web |title=BadVista: We hardly knew ye |url=http://badvista.fsf.org/blog/windows-7-launch-is-a-victory-for-badvista |author=BadVista.org team |accessdate=2009-01-10 }}</ref> This victory claim was based on the tepid adoption of Vista, compared to those sticking with the less-[[Digital Rights Management|DRM]] infused [[Windows XP]] or moving to the FSF-defined less restrictive [[Mac OS X]] or entirely free [[GNU/Linux]] or [[FreeBSD]].
===Windows 7 Sins=== A new campaign, this time targeted towards [[Windows 7]], has been launched under the name "Windows 7 Sins".<ref>[http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9137119/Free_software_group_attacks_Windows_7_sins_ Free software group attacks Windows 7 'sins'] ''COMPUTERWORLD'', August 26, 2009</ref> The site uses graphics from the [[open source video game|free software video game]] [[XBill]].
